sections.title: Module Credit and Completion Requirements and Learning Objective
sections.body:
Credit and Completion Requirements

To successfully earn credit and meet the learning objectives of this Web-Based Learning Application, it is essential to engage with every page, complete all knowledge checks, and complete the initial and final assessment independently. The assessment will require a 70% passing rate and while you are encouraged to refer to your notes of the course content during the assessment, any form of cheating is discouraged. Please also note that this course will expire by April 25, 2025.

Module Learning Objectives

Upon successful completion of the module, you will be able to:

  • Familiarize with common project management terms and methodologies including fundamentals, tools, skills, techniques, roles, and responsibilities.
  • Understand the different phases of a project: initiation, planning, execution, monitoring and controlling, and closing
  • Recognize the key activities, deliverables, and goals for each phase
  • To be equipped with the foundational knowledge needed to initiate, plan, execute, and close projects successfully

sections.title: Overview of Project Management
sections.subheader: Defining Project Management Through the Project Management Triangle
sections.body:
A project is defined as a temporary, goal-driven endeavor with a defined scope and resources, distinct from routine operations, aimed at delivering a unique outcome.

The Project Management Institute (PMI) defines Project Management as the disciplined application of knowledge, skills, tools, and techniques to plan, organize, and execute tasks throughout a project's lifecycle to meet its requirements and deliver tangible outcomes

The Project Management Triangle

  • Illustrates the changes to any of the three constrained elements — Scope, Cost or Time — results in changes to the other two due to their interdependent relationship.
  • The calibration of Cost, Scope, Time – varies depending on scenario/driver.

sections.title: Project Team, Project Manager, and Project Management Office (PMO)
sections.col1:
Members of a Project Team

  • Project Sponsor - is accountable for the project's success, ensuring its strategic significance, securing funding and approvals, gaining stakeholder support, and empowering the project manager and team
  • Project Manager - drives project execution, bridging strategy and team, managing resources and constraints, and ensuring objectives are met to satisfy project needs
  • Project Management Office (PMO) - a Project Management Office (PMO) establishes and maintains project management standards, frameworks, and methodologies while overseeing major program changes
  • Functional Leads/Team Leaders - oversee specific skill-based areas, manage business unit functions, and ensure project milestones are met by providing expertise and guidance
  • Project Team/Team Members - ensure quality deliverables, address stakeholder needs, integrate efforts per the project plan, manage procurement, and drive project outcomes
sections.col2:
Importance of a Project Manager and Benefits of Establishing a PMO

Project Managers are primarily responsible for planning and orchestrating the activities needed to deliver the project scope while ensuring everything stays on time and within budget. In some cases, a PMO is established to support effective project delivery.

Setting-up a PMO ensures project control through governance structures, standardized processes, and methodologies to monitor and accelerate progress.

Key benefits of establishing a PMO:

  • Ensure effective communication and stakeholder engagement to align outcomes with program objectives.
  • Centralize project planning and oversight, providing transparency on activities, milestones, and progress.
  • Manage budget, resources, scope, and timelines while proactively identifying and mitigating risks.

sections.title: Nine Project Management Functions
sections.subheader: Project Managers play a critical role in planning and coordinating activities to successfully deliver projects within scope, timeline, and budget
sections.body:
Nine Functions of Project Management

  • The functions of a project management encompasses scope and deliverable planning, resource allocation, budget control, stakeholder and communication management, change control, dependency oversight, risk mitigation, and regular reporting.

Project management goes far beyond simple oversight. It requires strategic decision-making, strong leadership, and the ability to navigate challenges effectively.

sections.title: Tools, Techniques, and Frameworks
sections.subheader: The Project Management Method enhances efficiency, compliance, and resource optimization for successful projects
sections.body:
Project Management Methods:

Project Management Method

  • A Consulting method that describes a process-based approach to plan, coordinate and control the execution of our services at the project level.

Waterfall Methodology

  • Traditional project management methodologies often follow a very linear and sequential approach. The scope and requirements are defined at the very beginning, and any changes to the defined scope must be reassessed and analyzed.

Agile Methodology

  • Agile methodologies, however, follows an iterative and “growing” approach. It welcomes frequently changing requirements and builds upon the collaboration and creativity of the team.

sections.title: Tools, Techniques, and Frameworks
sections.subheader: Deep-dive into Agile and Hybrid Methodologies
sections.body:
Agileis an umbrella term for various types of software development approaches.

Popular Agile Approaches:

  • Scrum - is a project management approach that anchors itself on teamwork, accountability and iterative progress toward a well-defined goal. Customers or stakeholders are actively involved in each sprint (fixed timeframes to deliver a feature).
  • Kanban - is a framework that requires real-time communication of capacity and full transparency of work. Work items are presented visually on what is called a “Kanban board.”
  • Lean Software Development (LSD) - is an approach derived from the Lean Management. It is where the team produces a bare minimum version of a product, gathers feedback from users, and iterates it based on what they need and don’t need

The Hybrid Approach combines waterfall (traditional) and agile (adaptive) project management methodologies

sections.subheader: Project Lifecyle
sections.body:
Learning Objective

At the end of this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Manage end-to-end project cycle from initiation to closing, as well as in performing the execution of the project and continuous monitoring and control of the project

sections.title: The Project Lifecyle
sections.subheader: Ensures clarity and direction to drive efficiency and project success
sections.body: The project lifecycle is a critical framework that outlines the stages a project goes through from initiation to completion. Understanding this lifecycle is essential for effective project management, as it provides a structured approach to planning, executing, and closing projects. Typically divided into phases such as initiation, planning, execution, monitoring, and closure, each stage plays a vital role in ensuring that project objectives are met efficiently and effectively.

sections.title: Initiation Phase
sections.subheader: Projects are initiated to address regulatory, strategic, customer, and cost-driven changes
sections.col1: Projects start when a question needs to be answered, a challenge needs to be overcome or there is a need to pursue an improvement initiative. These examples show that many of our projects get their start through changes in regulations, legislation, customer demands, strategy, cost pressures or a combination of them.
sections.col2:
Example Scenarios

  • There are new banking regulations that require the performance of a new set of processes.
  • Recent legislative changes require safeguarding customer data with specific protections.
  • Customer demand for innovation necessitates developing a new mobile device camera.
  • Company expansion into a new region requires updating the business strategy.
  • High product costs necessitate cost reductions to improve profitability.

sections.title: The Initiation Phase
sections.subheader: Projects are initiated to address regulatory, strategic, customer, and cost-driven changes
sections.body:
Initiation Phase Defined

Projects start when a question needs to be answered, a challenge needs to be overcome or there is a need to pursue an improvement initiative. These examples show that many of our projects get their start through changes in regulations, legislation, customer demands, strategy, cost pressures or a combination of them.

This phase defines a new project or a new phase of an existing project

Example Scenarios

  • There are new banking regulations that require the performance of a new set of processes.
  • Recent legislative changes require safeguarding customer data with specific protections.
  • Customer demand for innovation necessitates developing a new mobile device camera.
  • Company expansion into a new region requires updating the business strategy.
  • High product costs necessitate cost reductions to improve profitability.

Obtaining project authorization marks the start of the Initiation Phase, with the Project Charter as its output

The process of creating the Project Charter serves to align stakeholder expectations and is used as foundation for preparing detailed plans all throughout the project lifecycle. When the project charter is approved by the Sponsor, the project becomes officially authorized.

sections.title: Initiation Phase
sections.subheader: Framing a project: key questions to understand the ins and outs of a project
sections.col1:
A Project Charter holds the initial answers to these key project questions

Possible Questions:

  • Why? - rationale, goals, and objectives for the project
  • What? - scope, deliverables, outcomes, and finalize
  • When? - project schedule
  • Who? - roles and responsibilities
  • How? - methodology, approach, budget and other resources
sections.col2:
Objectives Deliverables Workplan (O-D-W) principle can be utilized to answer key questions

The O-D-W principle guides the iterative development of a high-level plan, ensuring alignment with business needs and outcomes.

sections.title: Initiation Phase
sections.subheader: Utilizing the RACI Matrix
sections.body:
RACI Matrix

The RACI Matrix is a simple charting tool used to define responsibility for each task within a project. It ensures that each task is assigned to the appropriate person or department to align responsibilities and set clear expectations.

RACI is an acronym with each letter representing a different role to perform:

  • Responsible - The responsible employee physically does the work.
  • Accountable - The accountable employee oversees the work and is ultimately answerable for the activity or decision.
  • Consulted - The consulted employee offers advice or feedback to improve the work.
  • Informed - The informed party does not take part in the work but should be notified of the results.

sections.title: Planning Phase
sections.subheader: Components and Steps in Building a Robust Project Plan
sections.body:
Building a Project Plan

Generally, the Initiate Phase answered the overall When question. However, in the Plan Phase, our When questions go far beyond this high‐level question.

During the Plan phase, we start assigning people or roles to activities and tasks.

These Who questions might be:

  • Who is responsible for this deliverable?
  • Who reviews and approves this deliverable?
  • Who approves or decides the budget and resource issues for this activity or task?

sections.title: Planning Phase
sections.subheader: Integrating O-D-W Approach
sections.body: Incorporating the O-D-W principle into work plan development creates a more robust process, where each step influences the project triangle and impacts overall quality

sections.title: Planning Phase
sections.subheader: Each iteration of planning goes from a high-level strategic focus to a tactical, activity, and task focus
sections.col1:
Defining Milestones in a Project

Milestones are meaningful when communicating the status of a project with the project team, key stakeholders, and sponsors.

A milestone is reached, when at least one of the following is true:

  • Marks the completion of a group of related activities or deliverables
  • When key decisions or key deliverables must be completed for the project to advance
  • Is on the critical path for the project’s completion
  • Can be tied to another project such that the achievement of one of your project’s milestones may impact progress on other projects
  • Is agreed upon with the project team, key stakeholders and sponsors as a key point in the project
sections.col2:
High-level process development of a plan

A project plan should have a defined timeline with interconnected tasks, be tailored to its purpose, and adjust in detail based on the target audience.

sections.title: Planning Phase
sections.subheader: Implementing a Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) hierarchically decomposes project work into deliverable-oriented structures, developed top-down or bottom-up.
sections.body:
Defining WBS

A Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) is a listing of the discrete steps of work to be executed by a project team, described with an action orientation. WBS helps clarify the tasks to be delivered on a project over a scheduled period of time.

A Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) outlines the discrete, action-oriented tasks a project team must execute, providing clarity on deliverables and timelines.

The following can be used as inputs to assist with creating WBS:

  • Methodology
  • Statement of Work (SOW)
  • Business Case
  • Project Proposal or Project Charter
  • Engagement Letter
  • Previously issued reports (finding and recommendation, improvement materials, etc.)

Work that is not in the WBS is outside the scope of the project.

sections.title: Planning Phase
sections.subheader: Accurate estimating of time, resources, and costs is critical in project management, as poor estimates can lead to project and program failure
sections.col1:
Defining WBS

Work effort estimation follows a top-down or bottom-up WBS approach, with techniques varying based on project size, scope, and complexity.

  • Provide a quantitative assessment of the number of work periods to complete an activity
  • Provide range of uncertainty when estimating an activity (2 weeks +/- 2 days)
  • Document assumptions made to derive the estimates
  • Update the activity list with any further breakdowns as a result of the duration estimates
sections.col2:
Estimate the Resources and Costs

Project managers rely on experience, practice, and guidance from leaders to estimate resources and costs effectively.

sections.title: Planning Phase
sections.subheader: Milestones are most effective when all parties with a stake in the project are properly assigned and delegated to specific and well-defined tasks
sections.col1:
Defining Milestones

Milestones are essential markers that indicate when significant parts of a project are completed. They not only help track progress along the critical path but also ensure that key decisions are made on time and interdependencies between projects are managed effectively.

A milestone marks a point in time for which one or more of the following is true:

  • Key deliverables - milestones mark the completion of critical activities, deliverables, or decisions necessary for project advancement
  • Critical Path and Interdependencies - typically lie on the project’s critical path and can influence the progress of related projects
  • Consensus and Communication - milestones are established agreement with the project team, stakeholders, and sponsors, serving as important communication benchmarks
sections.col2:
Defining Assignment of Resources and Delegation

Assignment is the matchmaking of a resource to a task in a project plan

Assigning resources allows you to answer:

  • Who should be working on what task and when?
  • Have you assigned so many tasks that a resource is beyond capacity?
  • Are you expecting a resource to work on a task when they are not available?

Delegation is deciding the right person accompanied with responsibility and accountability to deliver a work effort

Revisit your project plan when delegating tasks:

  • What is the activity all about?
  • What needs to be delivered?
  • When do you expect to start and complete?
  • Are there any dependencies to consider?
  • Who are your workstream members?

sections.title: Planning Phase
sections.subheader: The Critical Path Method
sections.body:
The Critical Path Method (CPM) builds, calculates, and evaluates project activities to optimize the plan

Critical Path is a series of tasks that will extend the project’s end date, if those tasks are delayed. These tasks have a single, pre-determined time estimate. It can also be explained as the longest-duration path through a network diagram and determines the shortest time to complete the project.

It is worth noting that there may be tasks with a Float/Stack value which allows for a task to be delayed from its expected start date, but without impact to the project’s finish date.

sections.title: Six-steps — the ODW way
sections.subheader: Baselines
sections.col1:
Baselines capture a snapshot of project attributes at a specific moment, allowing management tools to compare initial conditions with subsequent changes. By identifying differences, project managers can adjust or recover the plan as needed, ultimately driving continuous improvement in project planning.

The Project Plan is ready for a baseline when:

  • The Project Manager has received all estimate and schedule inputs from team and has drafted the Project Plan and Schedule.
  • The Project Manager has met with the team, reviewed the plan and obtained buy-in for the plan.
  • The Project Manager has met and discussed the team’s proposed plan with executive leadership and receives approval or sign off
  • The Project Manager has met with the PMO to review and obtain sign off on the plan.
  • All team, leadership and client changes are included in the plan.

sections.title: Plan Development
sections.subheader: Defining Project Plan
sections.body:
A Project Plan is a documented plan critical to tracking progress and reporting status. It describes how the project will be executed, monitored, and controlled.

This plan is a summary level document containing the results of planning. It serves as a complement to the Project Charter and represents a more detailed view of specific work streams and activities conducted during the project.

sections.title: Plan Development
sections.subheader: Enumeration of supporting plans
sections.body:
Supplementing plans supporting the overall Project Plan baseline:

  • Communications Management Plan - component of the project management plan that describes how project communications will be planned, structured, monitored, and controlled
  • Stakeholder Engagement Plan - component of the project management plan and identifies the management strategies required to effectively engage stakeholders. The stakeholder management plan can be formal or informal, highly detailed or broadly framed, based on the needs of the project
  • Scope Management Plan - describes how the project scope will be planned, structured, and controlled
  • Change Control Plan - sets expectations on how the approach to changes will be managed, what defines a change, the purpose and role of the change control board, and the overall change management process
  • Risk Management Plan - component of the project management plan and describes how risk management activities will be structured and performed
  • Schedule Management Plan - establishes the criteria and the activities for developing, monitoring, and controlling the schedule

Purpose

sections.title: The Execution Phase
sections.subheader: Defining Best Practices for Being a Successful and Effective Project Manager
sections.col1:
Effective Ways for a Project Manager to Lead:

  • Motivating and inspiring - encouraging and prompting their people to do the best work possible and acknowledge those that produce both in public and private.
  • Team building - deliberately looking for opportunities to help team members work with each other to achieve their collective goals. On larger projects, project leadership fosters the process and mechanisms to enable sub-team leads to do the same.
  • Negotiating and communicating - project leaders' model desired and exemplary communication skills. This includes creating a healthy environment where open and honest communications carry throughout the team and stakeholders.
  • Listening and influencing - Project leaders’ must listen to their team members’ ideas and concerns — and then acknowledge and show consideration for their contribution to the discussion. This happens before the leader issues an opinion or decision.
sections.col2:
Project Execution

Project Managers manage the delivery of the work while leading the team and stakeholders through changes to the project triangle

Changes to time, scope and cost WILL happen. The Project manager must be prepared to lead the team through the process of adjusting the work plan and resetting expectations as the work develops.

Leaders will be aware that they (and the project) are being evaluated on achieving the stated outcomes of the project, the performance of the team and their ability to balance both the art and science of Project Management.

sections.title: The Monitoring and Control Phase
sections.subheader: Definition, Activities, and Benefits
sections.col1:
The Monitor and Control Phase consists of the following:

The Monitor and Control phase consists of:

  • Processes required to track, review and orchestrate the progress and performance of the project
  • Identify any areas in which changes to the plan are required
  • Initiate the corresponding changes

Aim of the Phase: Provide critical visibility and insight to project against plan and initiate corrective action as needed.
sections.col2:
Key Activities and Key Benefits:

Key Activities:

  • Control changes and recommend actions (preventive or corrective)
  • Monitor ongoing activities and gauge against project performance measures
  • Maintain project change control processes

Key Benefits:

  • Project performance is measured and analyzed at regular intervals, appropriate events
  • Able to identify variances from the project management plan

Structure and Roles

sections.title: The Monitoring and Control Phase
sections.subheader: Stakeholder management: Who are the stakeholders?
sections.col1:
Stakeholders are a range of people who have a vested interest in the project’s progress and success

  • Sponsor - owns the project, accountable for its delivery
  • Project Manager - responsible for successful delivery
  • Functional Leads - making investments in time/money
  • Key Stakeholders - clients, beneficiaries and/or impacted parties
  • Project Team - job satisfaction and reputations depend on it
  • Other PMs - may share dependencies and resources
sections.col2:
When effectively employed, stakeholder management is critical to a project’s success

  • Achievement of strategic objectives through positive relationships with stakeholders
  • Proactive management of expectations through a defined process
  • Consistent communications use and information dissemination using a common language
  • Effective Change Management activities using a formalized process and discipline

sections.title: The Monitoring and Control Phase
sections.subheader: Stakeholder Management: Who are the stakeholders?
sections.body:
Identify stakeholders

  • Identify all key people or groups impacted by the project

Plan communications

  • Determine the stakeholder information needs and define and plan communications approach

Distribute and communicate information

  • Make relevant information available to project stakeholders as planned, using methods/media that are fit-for-purpose

Manage stakeholder expectations

  • Communicate and work with stakeholders to meet their priority needs and address issues/concerns as they occur

Communicate performance

  • Collect and communicate performance information, including status reports, progress measurement and forecasts

sections.title: The Monitoring and Control Phase
sections.subheader: Using RACI and RAID matrices to establish effective governance sets the project up for success
sections.body:
• The ultimate success of the Project Manager depends on governance. Stakeholder management and governance standards, processes, and participants are brought to life by the Project Manager.
  • The effectiveness of the Project Manager in establishing and supporting the governance processes will greatly impact the successful outcomes of the overall project.
  • Utilizing the RACI Matrix ensures effective management of stakeholder expectations.

Defining the RAID Matrix:

  • The RAID matrix allows the project team to document, proactively account for, and address items interrelated with the project.
  • The staff on a project is often responsible for identifying the risks and helping to complete the RAID tool.
  • Unlike risks and issues, assumptions and dependencies in the RAID log are documented instances where the project has determined that there is an assumption or dependency which exists, so that in the process of resolving issues or mitigating risks, these factors are not missed — and can be incorporated into the solution.

sections.title: The Monitoring and Control Phase
sections.subheader: Sample RAID Log
sections.body: The sample shows how issues, risks, and dependencies are being recorded and mitigated.

sections.title: The Monitoring and Control Phase
sections.subheader: Your Response to Risks Identified
sections.body:
ACCEPT

  • It might not always be cost-effective to avoid, transfer, or mitigate all risks, at some point a certain level of risk must be accepted.

AVOID

  • Risk avoidance is the simplest response strategy – basically this involves just not going forward with the activity that posed the risk.

TRANSFER

  • Risk transfer strategies seek to pass the risk off to a third party.

MITIGATE

  • Risk mitigation involves trying to reduce an existing risk.

sections.title: The Monitoring and Control Phase
sections.subheader: Your Response to Risks Identified
sections.body:
This issue lifecycle is straightforward. The process helps the project team to understand what to do with issues once identified. The Project Manager should ensure that the project team has the required skills to facilitate the movement of an issue throughout the process.

Project Managers should be able to answer the following questions regarding issue control:

  • Who will be assigned for resolving the issue?
  • How will the team know when to escalate an issue to management or the steering committee?
  • Consider creating a matrix of potential business impact versus issue complexity to help decide which issues should be taken to higher levels of management.
  • Which criteria will determine an issue's priority status?
  • Who will set the target resolution date?; How will issues be communicated within the team?

sections.title: The Monitoring and Control Phase
sections.subheader: Creating a Project Status Report
sections.body:
Defining Status Reports

  • Status Report is a summary of an ongoing project performance information for a specific period of time.
  • It is regularly updated and presented to key stakeholders and sponsor all throughout the execution of a project.
  • Timeline, Cost, and Scope changes typically happen during Execution. A Project Manager must be prepared to manage the delivery of the work while leading the team through the process of adjusting the work plan and resetting expectations as the work develops.
  • A Project Manager should also continuously refresh and affirm many of the tasks, inputs and outputs in all of the phases from Initiate through Monitor and Control.
  • Some of the foundational documents will need updating throughout the project, and sometimes a formal Change Request is needed.

sections.title: The Closing Phase
sections.subheader: Conclude all activities and formally complete the project, phase, or contractual obligation
sections.col1:
Key Activities:

  • Submit materials to knowledge management tools
  • Confirm project outcomes have been achieved
  • Conduct a project close meeting with the Project Sponsor/s
  • Conduct a team debrief
  • Release project resources
  • Perform the administrative close

This activity, when completed, verifies that the defined processes are completed within to close the project or a project phase, as appropriate, and formally establishes that the project or project phase is complete.​
sections.col2:
Important Outputs:

  • Accepted deliverables
  • Supplier contract close document
  • Corrective actions
  • Team performance assessments
  • Documented lessons learned
  • Team resources released
  • Project close report

sections.title: The Closing Phase
sections.subheader: Project team debrief and lessons learned
sections.col1:
Elements of a good project team debrief include:

  • Input from all teams (including client members, if appropriate)
  • Clear expectations of transparency
  • Discussion addresses mobilization, communications, planning, quality, resourcing and teaming
  • Conduct a team debrief
  • Team members are prepared to share observations of lessons learned

The project team debrief serves as a key component and event in the close process. The meeting can be held with or without the client team members, depending on the type and nature of the project. ​
sections.col2:
Project Managers’ Role During Debriefs:

The Project Manager should prepare the team members to provide honest and open feedback on how well the project was executed. During the meeting, team members will discuss mobilization, communications, planning, quality, resourcing and teaming. Of critical importance is the identification, capture and discussion of lessons learned.

Asking questions such as:

  • What worked well and why?
  • What did not work well and why?
  • How could the team do better next time?

sections.title: The Closing Phase
sections.subheader: Defining the Closing Report
sections.col1:
Defining the Closing Report:

Summarizes the overall performance of a project against objectives, deliverables, and milestones. Includes a simplified view of any remaining outstanding issues and variance analysis in project scope, time, and cost.​

The Project Manager presents the final report to the client project sponsor and other key stakeholders and must obtain an approval to close the project.

If there are outstanding issues preventing the sponsor from approving the close, the Project Manager and sponsor should create an action plan with a planned completion date.
sections.col2:
Components of a Closing Report

  • Executive Summary - provide a brief overview of the project, its objectives, and high-level outcomes
  • Project Objectives - specify any deviations from the original objectives
  • Scope - highlight any scope creep or changes in the project
  • Deliverables - group into milestones and highlight specific challenges
  • Successes - discuss any notable milestones and accomplishments
  • Challenges - discuss here how these challenges were addressed
  • Lessons learned - explain and discuss how these lessons can be applied to future projects
  • Risk Management - mention if they materialized or not
  • Quality and performance - explain here the project’s quality control process
  • Recommendations - discuss future pursuits or projects

We hope this module has empowered you with the knowledge and confidence to tackle any financial challenge that comes your way. Keep honing your skills, stay diligent in your financial planning, and continue to strive for excellence in budget and cost management.
